qas.question: How many ways can a verb in an aspect pair differ?
What does a perfective verb have added in prefix pairs?
What is added to the ending in suffix pairs?
What can imperfective verb undergo to make other imperfective verbs?
What type of action can second level morphed imperfective verbs denote?

plausible_answers.text: na-, o-, po-, s-, u-, vy-, z- and za

qas.question: What are the most common suffixes?
What is added to the perfective stem in a prefix pair?
What might prefixes have happen to make other imperfective verbs?
What kind of action can morphed prefixes be a sign of?
In what two ways are perfective stems different?

context: The verbs of most aspect pairs differ in one of <a0_0>two ways<a0_0/>: <b9_0>by prefix or by suffix<b9_0/>. In prefix pairs, the perfective verb has <a1_0><b6_0>an added prefix<b6_0/><a1_0/>—for example, the imperfective psát (to write, to be writing) compared with the perfective napsat (to write down, to finish writing). The most common prefixes are <b5_0>na-, o-, po-, s-, u-, vy-, z- and za<b5_0/>-. In suffix pairs, a <a2_0>different infinitive ending<a2_0/> is added to the perfective stem; for example, the perfective verbs koupit (to buy) and prodat (to sell) have the imperfective forms kupovat and prodávat. Imperfective verbs may undergo <a3_0>further <b7_0>morphology<b7_0/><a3_0/> to make other imperfective verbs (iterative and frequentative forms), denoting <a4_0><b8_0>repeated or regular action<b8_0/><a4_0/>. The verb jít (to go) has the iterative form chodit (to go repeatedly) and the frequentative form chodívat (to go regularly).
